conclusion: Consider the effects of gravity and air resistance on the basketball's motion.
The basketball is dropped from rest at height H.
The gravitational force acting on the basketball is mg.
The air resistance force is λmg.
The net force during descent is (1 - λ)mg.
The acceleration during descent is a1 = (1 - λ)g.
Using kinematic equation, velocity just before impact is v1 = sqrt(2(1 - λ)gH).
The basketball rebounds to a height h.
The net force during ascent is (1 + λ)mg.
The acceleration during ascent is a2 = (1 + λ)g.
Using kinematic equation, velocity just after impact is v2 = sqrt(2(1 + λ)gh).
The ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity is v2/v1 = sqrt((1 + λ)h/(1 - λ)H).
